data.title: Allow Enabling useCodeSnippetsOnMethodSuggest for JS As Well As TS
data.body:
Fixes #13952

**Bug**
The `typescript.useCodeSnippetsOnMethodSuggest` setting only applies to Typescript files. I believe it should also apply to JavaScript files.

**Fix**
Use `typescript.useCodeSnippetsOnMethodSuggest` to control this behavior for js files as well.

An alternate design would be to add a `javascript.useCodeSnippetsOnMethodSuggest` configuration option, if users really do want to have different behavior between JS and TS.

Also delete unused configuration file.

data.title: Disable Autoclosing Quotes in Python Strings and Comments
data.body:
Fixes #8539

**Bug**
In python file, typing `'` in a string or comment results in `''` due to auto closing pairs.

**fix**
Apply same fix that we use for Typescript to disable this behavior in strings and comments https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/typescript/language-configuration.json

data.title: Copying a selection across multiple filtered settings includes extraneous text

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: branch `sandy081/exploreConfiguration`
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In settings, filter by some text string in the filter box, for example "Save"
2. Select text across multiple settings that show up in this filtered mode
3. Copy to the clipboard and paste somewhere to examine.
4. Note that the copied text can include text that appeared to never be in the selection.


This was my selection:
![screen shot 2016-12-01 at 3 38 55 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11839736/20817483/d76dd0f4-b7dc-11e6-848e-50c9a4700322.png)


And this was the output I got after copying and pasting:
```
//Controls the delay in ms after which a dirty file is saved automatically. Only applies when "files.autoSave" is set to "afterDelay"
    "files.autoSaveDelay": 1000,

    //Configure glob patterns of file paths to exclude from file watching. Changing this setting requires a restart. When you experience Code consuming lots of cpu time on startup, you can exclude large folders to reduce the initial load.
    "files.watcherExclude": {
        "**/.git/objects/**": true,
        "**/node_modules/**": true
    },

    //Controls whether unsaved files are restored after relaunching. If this is enabled there will be no prompt to save when exiting the editor.
    "files.hotExit": false,
```

data.title: Bad Stuff happens when you press the enter key in the search box quickly
data.body: Worker processes are created for each search. When a search is canceled, they are shut down. They need time to close their open files, so the processes aren't killed immediately. This means that if you start and cancel searches really fast, you can run up a very large number of processes. Then Code stops responding.

data.title: Enable Strict Null Checks and Use Lib References in Markdown Extension
data.body:
Makes a few changes to the markdown extension:

* Enables strict null checks.
* Enables no implicit any checks.
* Switch to using TS 2.0 lib files.

This change required removing the mocha declaration from the shared `declare.d.ts`. Everything seems to compile fine without it.

data.title: Inconsistent behavior when cutting and pasting line with no selection

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0-insider
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Put cursor on a word with no text selected (over 1234)
  ```
  ab
  1234
  ab
  ```
2. Cut the line (ctrl+x)
```
ab
ab
```
3. Focus a different text editor tab and then return focus to original tab (ctrl+tab twice)
4. Move the cursor to the middle of a word (right arrow key)
5. Paste the line (ctrl+v)
```
ab
a1234
b
```

Expected: original text.

Pasting should work the same as if the tab hadn't changed. Cutting and pasting a line in the same file works, but if the tab changes then it pastes in the middle of the word instead of the beginning of the line.

data.title: Jenkinsfile are groovy too
Add context actions along the lines of IntelliJ
data.body:
- VSCode Version:Version 1.8.0-insider
- OS Version: Ubuntu

Steps to Reproduce:

1. New feature request

Currently in vscode, user can associate a shortcut to a command (or) can add a right click menu item to perform an operation either in the editor/sidebar/panel.

But IntelliJ has an additional type of provision to allow developers to contribute to generators via `alt+insert` key. This allows additional context dependent actions to be added.

For eg., if you press `alt+insert` in typescript editor, you will see actions that allows you to perform operations on the typescript file, such as generate setter,create constructor, e.t.c

If you press the same combination in explorer on a directory, you will see popup-actions to add a new file/new directory/new typescript/e.t.c

This `alt+insert` is a powerful way to reduce the total number of shortcuts, as it allows the contributors to target this `alt+insert` instead of forcing the user to remember a lot of shortcuts for every action. This shortcut is context dependent & allows structural modifications to the current panel/editor at hand.

Please check if this can be added to the core so that developers can contribute in a better way at the same time it will be less overhead on the user aswell, as user will then only need to remember `alt+insert` instead of a lot of shortcuts.

data.title: In-product release notes h2 and h3 links cause topic to go blank
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.7.2 
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Help > Release Notes
2. Click on a Highlight (h3) or section (h2) link at the top of the in-product release notes page.
The page goes blank.
This will also happen if you do the same with Markdown preview on https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/blob/master/release-notes/v1_7.md.
This is a regression with 1.7.2. 1.7.0 and 1.7.1 don't have the issue.
@mjbvz investigated and has a fix.


data.title: Fix markdown preview anchor links
data.body:
**Bug**
In the markdown preview, clicking on a anchor link causes the editor to go blank. This effects our release notes.

**Fix**
Fix the webview pre script which was accidentally changed when it was extracted in 0cef61f4f4d8a73a00f8da28bdf9b7af0a11e4ef


Fixes #16337

FYI @gregvanl

data.title: Smarter search batching
data.body:
If the search process batch isn't filled in 2 seconds, it's sent to the frontend anyway. After 50 results are returned, it reverts to the original batching behavior. Also fixed to batch by actual number of results, instead of 'number of files with matches' which it ended up doing before.

Fixes #16284

data.title: Scroll bar overlaying on top of text
data.body:
Description:
When word wrap is turned on, a long line of text should be line-breaking before the beginning of the editor window's scroll bar. Instead, the text is reaching the very end of the editor window (including the scrollbar) before line-breaking.

NOTE: I just noticed that this only happens when:
a. a period (.) is at the beginning of a line OR
b. a space is inserted before/after a backslash (but this is random to me and I haven’t discerned a noticeable pattern).

Example:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1090861/20804243/c25131ae-b7b7-11e6-92d3-5c58c8ce73cc.png)

- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: MacOS El Capitan (10.11.6)

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Create a new editor window with `View > Word Wrap` enabled.
2. Paste the following into the first line: `a/very/long/line/of/text/that/expands/beyond/your/typical/line/of/code///decrease/the/width/of/your/editor/window/to/see/the/line/breaking/in/action`.
3. Decrease the width of your editor window so that a word wrap occurs.
4. Add a period or space to the very beginning of the text OR add a space before or after the first forward-slash (right after "a").

data.title: Allow DocumentLinkProvider define to which line in file we want navigate
data.body: Right now `DocumentLinkProvider` defines it's target as a `Uri`. Unfortunately this doesn't allow us to define to which line we want to navigate. I wonder if we could extend API a bit to support navigation to specific line.

data.title: Use cached data to speed up script parsing
data.body: V8 allows to create a script with cached data from previous runs. With that parsing time is reduced a lot: http://v8project.blogspot.co.uk/2015/07/code-caching.html. For us, it means that the average for loading `workbench.main.js` drops from 880ms to ~615ms (tested on my MBP).

data.title: Use graceful-fs in searchWorker
data.body: To get rid of the code I added to avoid having too many open files.

data.title: Test: View scalability
data.body:
Test for #15155:

- [x] Windows - @seanmcbreen
- [x] OS X -  @cdias
- [x] Linux - @bgashler1 

Complexity: 4

In order to support scenarios where extensions contribute viewlets to the activity bar, some work was done to enable scalability in the activity bar.

**Setup:**
* get https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/master/tree-explorer-sample
* npm install
* run it from VS Code as extension

**Verify**
* you can show the contributed viewlet by 
   * using the new `View > Additional Viewlets` entry
   * right clicking on empty space in activity bar and selecting it
   * by using the new view picker (quick open -> type "`view `" with a trailing space)
* if you make the window small enough, viewlets that do not fit the space move into a new "..." overflow menu
   * entries in the overflow menu still indicate activity as decoration to their label
   * the current active viewlet is indicated in the overflow menu if inside
* you can move viewlets around via DND and the position is remembered between restarts
* you can remove viewlets from the activity bar and bring them back by
   * unchecking them from the activity bar context menu
   * right clicking on the viewlet and pick the related action to remove
   * removed viewlets still show up at the end of all viewlets when they are active but hide once another viewlet opens
* you can bring back a removed viewlet either by 
   * using the context menu on the empty space of activity bar
   * by opening it and from the context menu select the related entry to keep it

Verify some corner cases where you combine:
* overflow of viewlets so you see the "..."
* reordering of viewlets
* keeping/removing viewlets

Watch out for crashes in the console in that case, there may well be some layouting bugs 👍

data.title: Open Recent Folder in Windows Taskbar menu fails with spaces in folder path
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 AU

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a folder with a space in the folder name (i.e. "C:\temp\Some Folder")
2. Open in Code
3. Close Code
4. Right click on VS Code icon in taskbar
5. Select C:\temp\Some Folder from Recent Folders list in taskbar popup menu
6. Code opens with two new files created: C:\temp\Some and C:\Windows\system32\Folder and no current folder
![2016-12-01_9-52-29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4534445/20798335/8025af04-b7ac-11e6-9c89-e956821fc5bb.png)
![2016-12-01_9-53-06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4534445/20798336/8026dc08-b7ac-11e6-9bdf-8dc8cba1500a.png)
